messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "sharpe_simon" <s.sharpe@d...> wrote:
> I hope to use JUNIT to teach programming to my Y1 students this year.
> I'd planned to write the test class, then ask the students to write
> the code e.g for a Book class, a test in the TestBook class might
> look like this.
>
<SNIP>
> Problem : - I want them to work through the exercises and tests one
> at a time, but the test class will obviously not compile until all
> of the correct methods are in place in the Book class.
> Is my approach to this incorrect. Is there better way?
>
> Hope you can help.

It depends on what you would like to teach your students. If you are
trying to create an assigment where they learn to write code that
accomplishes certain objectives, and you're not teaching a particular
development method, you might be better served using a tool like
Fitnesse (http://www.fitnesse.org/). You define a series of tests
that the students code must pass, and when the student runs the tests
each one is tagged as a success or failure. The advantage is that
this framework does not require the methods to be written yet in order
for the tests to run.

You could introduce JUnit as a tool to help your students write more
reliable code that passes the acceptance tests you define using Fitnesse.

Hope this helps!
Carl
